The CATOFIN© process produces propylene from propane using a CrOx /Al2O3 catalyst. Despite its use, there are still uncertainties surrounding the nature of Cr species formed during synthesis, regeneration, and aging. It has been observed that ppm levels of Cr2O3 can be oxidized to Cr(VI) in air; however, when Cr2O3 is in direct contact with Al2O3, Cr(VI) formation increased more than 100-fold. To confirm physical contact between Cr2O3 and Al2O3 results in increased Cr(VI) formation, Cr2O3 and Cr2O3/Al2O3 samples were synthesized, calcined, and characterized. Catalytic activity measurements confirm propylene selectivity inversely tracks with Cr(VI). Wet chemical titration and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) quantified and determined the structure of the Cr(VI) species. FEFF X-ray absorption near edge structure simulations determined the potential sensitivity of the XAS to the presence of Al3+/Cr3+ neighboring atoms. XAS correlated to FEFF simulations suggested that Al3+ xCr3+ 2−xCr6+ 3O12 comprises a significant fraction of the Cr(VI) species formed. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Dehydrogenation CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst XAS XANES Chromium oxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CrOx/Al2O3 is a commonly used industrial catalyst for propane dehydrogenation (e.g. CATOFIN© process), and it has been a subject of numerous studies over the past century [1–19]. During the lifespan of catalyst the CrOx/Al2O3 undergoes multiple structural changes from CrOx particles sintering, solid solutions of Al2−xCrxO3 forming, clogging or closing of pores and the constant formation and disappearance of multiple Cr(VI) species, all affecting the activity and selectivity of the catalyst [20–22]. Despite extensive efforts to understand the chemical intricacies of this system, there are still several questions that remain unanswered. One such question involves the nature of Cr(VI) species formed during catalyst preparation and oxidative regeneration [22]. The concentration of Cr(VI) in the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst is typically on the ppm level [20,21], complicating efforts to identify all Cr(VI)-containing species. While the concentration of this Cr species is low it is of interest to understand Cr(VI) speciation since this can provide further insight into catalyst deactivation mechanisms and potential for improvement. It is well established that some Cr(VI) species in CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst are formed during impregnation of the alumina carrier by aqueous solutions of CrO3 or Cr(NO3)3 [23,24]. This Cr(VI) formation is postulated to form during the deposition of chromium (III) oxide on the surface of Al2O3, which undergoes a sequential consumption of the hydroxyl group forming mono-aluminum chromate and poly-aluminum chromate species. The presence of the Cr(VI) species results in a decreased selectivity, favoring cracking products over propene during the propane dehydrogenation step [21]. During the drying and calcination, a majority of these aluminum chromate species are decomposed to chromium (III) oxide species. However, as shown by Fridman et al., a small portion of the mono and poly-aluminum chromate species are stable enough to survive the final calcination step [22]. These Cr(VI) species can be named as aluminum chromate species produced by impregnation. Moreover, new Cr(VI) species were observed to be formed during the final calcination step by re-oxidation of Cr2O3 [21,22]. This conclusion was made based on the observation that the concentration of new Cr(VI) species in the CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst depends on the O2 concentration in the calcination atmosphere. Additionally, authors of these publications conducted direct oxidation experiments of Cr2O3 alone and Cr2O3 mixed with high surface area Al2O3. These experiments revealed that calcination of Cr2O3 alone in air at 600 °C oxidized only ppm levels of Cr2O3 to Cr(VI) forming chromium chromate, Cr3+ 2Cr6+ 3O12. However, when Cr2O3 was in direct contact with Al2O3, the rate of Cr2O3 oxidation in air at 600 °C into Cr(VI) was increased by more than 100-fold. Based on this observation, the authors speculated that oxidation of Cr2O3 is possible during catalyst preparation as well as during the regeneration step of the CATOFIN© dehydrogenation process, with the majority of oxidation expected to occur at the interface of chromia and alumina oxides. Although the authors did not have direct evidence, they speculated that most likely these new Cr(VI) species are the Al3+ xCr3+ 2−xCr6+ 3O12, or chromium-aluminum-chromate, produced by re-oxidation of Cr2O3 [21,22]. The objective of the current work is to further investigate this hypothesis by using X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and XAS theory to probe the electronic and geometric structure of the Cr species in CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts and mixtures to better speciate the Cr(VI) species formed during the calcination process. Prior works have used X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) to quantify the amount of Cr(VI) in supported Cr materials through calibration curves of the pre-edge peak intensity formed in Cr(VI) oxides [25], or using linear combination fitting to resolve the evolution of the Cr oxidation state [26] during the calcination of supported Cr catalyst. Modeling of extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) has been used on supported Cr catalysts in oxidized, reduced, or post dehydrogenation (ethane or propane) to determine the average local atomic structure [27–29]. While these methods give insight into the average oxidation sates (or fractions thereof) they lack the detailed analysis required to identify the subtle differences between the formation of chromium chromate (-Cr(III)-O-Cr(IV)-) and aluminum chromate (-Al(III)-O-Cr(IV)-). Advanced analytics such as principal component analysis and multivariate curve resolution-alternating least squares have been used to identify various Cr species that are similar to bulk compounds during ethane dehydrogenation but the analysis did not go into what caused the subtle variations [30]. Herein, we use XANES analysis techniques coupled with FEFF XANES simulations and EXAFS modeling to quantify the amount of Cr(VI) formed during synthesis or calcination of CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts and determine the Cr(VI) speciation beyond what is currently present in the literature. While the industrial catalyst contains small amounts of additives, including alkali metals, these were intentionally not added in our study. Using a set of samples where the Cr content is varied between industrially relevant (38 wt% Cr) and dilute (0.6 wt% Cr) we are able to skew the formation of Cr(VI) during calcination making it easier to characterize. We are able to confirm that one of the species formed during the lifespan (during synthesis, calcination or oxidative regeneration steps) of a CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst is an aluminum-chromium-chromate species (Al3+ xCr3+ 2−xCr6+ 3O12) and it is due to the contact between CrOx and Al2O3. 2 Experimental 2.1 Samples The samples used in this study are listed in Table 1. The Cr5O12 (Pfaltz & Bauer, Inc, 99.5% purity) and K2Cr2O7 (Sigma Aldrich, 99.9% purity) were used as spectral standards. The Cr2O3 was prepared by calcination of CrO3 flake (Elementis, 99.91% purity) at 760 °C for 2 h. Mixture A was prepared by mixing the required amounts of Cr2O3 powder, described above, with Al2O3 powder (Clariant, >99% purity) at room temperature. Half of Mixture A was calcined at 600 °C for 2 h to make Mixture B. Impregnated samples were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of alumina using aqueous solutions of CrO3 (Catalyst C and E) or Cr(NO3)3 (Catalyst D) to achieve the target Cr loading of 0.6–13 wt%. These impregnated samples were then calcined in air at 750 °C for 2 h prior to analysis. 2.2 Wet chemical analysis Total Cr and Cr6+ amounts listed in Table 1 were determined by wet chemical analysis. The mixtures and catalysts were analyzed according to standard methods [31]. To determine the total Cr and Cr6+ concentration, the sample was digested by a mixture of sulfuric and phosphoric acid. A titration method was applied for analysis of total Cr, and Cr6+ was measured with application of colorimetry. 2.3 Dehydrogenation activity test Dehydrogenation activity tests were conducted in a unit that simulates the commercial cyclic dehydrogenation-regeneration process and is operated in successive cycles of reduction, dehydrogenation, and regeneration. The detailed testing procedure has been previously described [22]. To obtain Catalyst E, aged, the fresh Catalyst E was thermally treated in cyclic redox mode at 600 °C for 300 cycles. This method of catalyst treatment was validated by comparing the properties of an industrial-like 13% Cr/Al2O3 catalyst with those having similar composition but taken from a commercial reactor 300 cycles of operation. Activity of the fresh and aged catalysts was tested by the dehydrogenation of propane at a pressure of 0.5 bar (absolute), a reaction contact time of 0.83 s, and in the temperature range of 550–575 °C. The average propylene selectivity and yield reported for catalysts was determined by averaging the results of each catalyst for 15 reduction-dehydrogenation-regeneration cycles at 550 and 575 °C. 2.4 X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) X-ray absorption spectra were collected at beamline 4–3 at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource (SSRL). Beamline 4–3 is a side-station beamline on a wiggler source with a Si collimating mirror and double-crystal, liquid nitrogen-cooled monochromator with a Si(111) phi = 0 crystal set. The Si(111) crystal set used in the measurements has a glitch located at 5987.6 eV located just before the Cr K-edge that is in a similar, though resolvable position to the Cr(III) and Cr(VI) pre-edge peaks occurring at approximately 5993.4 eV. We have chosen not to deglitch our XAS spectra. For Cr K-edge XAS measurements the collimating mirror was set to a 10 keV cutoff energy, the monochromator was tuned 100% at 6489.0 eV, and the ionization chambers were filled with N2 with a 1800 VDC negative polarity bias. For total fluorescence yield measurements, a PIPS diode was used to measure fluorescence signal. A Cr foil was scanned simultaneously for absolute energy calibration. The beamline was calibrated to Cr K-edge, 5989.0 eV, using the maximum of the first derivative of the Cr foil XAS spectrum. Samples of Cr2O3/Al2O3 for XAS measurements were prepared by diluting the catalyst with cellulose in a 1:4 ratio by mass. Approximately 15 mg of the diluted sample was pressed into a 7 mm diameter pellet and sealed between two layers of 0.025 mm thick Kapton™ tape. For samples with a metal loading of 1 wt% Cr and higher, transmission XAS spectra were recorded, for metal loadings lower than 1 wt% Cr, fluorescence XAS spectra were recorded. Reference oxides of Cr(III) and Cr(VI), Cr3+ 2O3, Cr3+/6+ 5O12, K2Cr6+ 2O7, and Cr6+O3, were prepared in a similar manner. The dilution ratio and packing mass were set such that the sample and reference pellets had a thickness of 2.5 absorption lengths at approximately 6040 eV. XAS spectra were collected in transmission geometry with a Cr foil collected simultaneously in transmission geometry for energy alignment during data analysis. Two to four spectra were collected to improve signal-to-noise. A transmission spectrum of a Cr foil (thickness 2 µm) was initially collected for energy calibration purposes. 2.5 XAS data analysis XAS spectra were processed using the Demeter software package [32]. Spectra were imported into Athena where they were energy calibrated, normalized, and merged. Spectra were energy calibrated by aligning the reference Cr foil spectrum (collected simultaneously with the sample spectra) to a pre-calibrated Cr foil spectrum at 5989.0 eV. The edge energy, E0, for the Cr2O3/Al2O3 and reference samples was set to 6003.0 eV, an average value for the inflection points of the Cr K-edge of each spectrum. Normalization curves were defined from E0-150 to E0-30 eV for the pre-edge curve, and from E0 + 75 to E0 + 500 eV for the post-edge curve. The post edge curve was fit with a 3rd order polynomial given the curvature of the absorption spectra across the fitted energy range. Two to four spectra were merged to improve signal-to-noise. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra of the mixtures A and B and catalysts C and D were modeled using the Artemis software in the Demeter package [32]. The passive electronic reduction factor, S0 2, was determined to be 0.85 based upon modeling the EXAFS spectrum of a Cr foil, Fig. S1 and Table S1 in the SI, using the first two Cr-Cr single scattering paths obtained from a Cr metal cif file (mp-90, from the Materials Project [33]). The EXAFS spectra of the two mixture samples, A and B, each before and after calcination, along with a Cr2O3 standard were modeled simultaneously to reduce the error in each fitted parameter. The k- and R-ranges fit were 2.62–11.80 Å−1 and 1.0–2.1 Å, respectively. The EXAFS models for each sample and reference consisted of the first two Cr-O single-scattering paths of a Cr2O3 cif file, mp-19399, from the Materials Project [33], with effective scattering path lengths of 1.96 and 2.01 Å, respectively. Every spectrum simultaneously fit had a unique energy correction term, ΔE0, to account for subtle changes in the edge position that was assumed to be constant for all spectra. Each path fit for a given spectrum had a unique coordination number, and ΔR parameter. All paths fit, independent of sample, had a shared disorder parameter, σ2, based upon the assumption that all single-scattering paths at a similar distance would have a similar disorder term. An alternative model to describe the samples was also simultaneously fit. This model included the addition of a short single-scattering Cr-O path, with an effective path length of approximately 1.65 Å, found in Cr(VI) containing oxides. When using the 3-path model the same parameters were shared as above, however the short Cr-O paths shared a second σ2 parameter [33]. Quantification of the Cr(VI) and Cr(III) fractions was determined from the EXAFS analysis based upon the fraction of Cr-O coordination between 4 and 6. These values correspond to the bulk Cr-O coordination found in Cr(VI) or Cr(III) oxides, respectively. It was also assumed that the first scattering paths of oxides are insensitive to particle sizes [34]. Linear combination fitting (LCF) was performed using the Athena software. X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra were fit from E0-20 to E0 + 30 eV, an energy range that included the pre-edge features as well as the first oscillation in the spectra past the white line. Each calcined sample was fit three times, with each fit only including two basis spectra. Basis spectra consisted of the XANES spectrum of Cr2O3 and a spectrum of either Cr5O12, K2Cr2O7, or CrO3. During the LCF the basis spectra were constrained to fractions between 0 and 1, while the total fraction (sum of each basis spectrums weighting) was not constrained. Difference analysis [35–37], defined in Eq. (1), was used to extract the XAS spectrum of an unknown species that was formed during the calcination process. The spectrum extraction of the unknown species was performed by exporting normalized “final” and “initial” state spectra from Athena, and then manipulating the data in Excel. The unknown state species was reimported into Athena for EXAFS extraction. (1) Final State − x Initial State 1 − x = Unknown State XAS spectra of Mixtures A and B were used as initial and final states, respectively. The fraction of initial species, x, was set from a range of 0.88–0.95 based upon the results of the LCF analysis, discussed below. 2.6 FEFF XANES simulations Simulation of the Cr K-edge (5989 eV) XANES for various Cr oxide structures was completed using the FEFF 10.0 code. Clusters of radii 5.0 Å and 8.0 Å were used for the Self Consistent Field (SCF) and Full Multiple Scattering (FMS) simulations, respectively, in order to obtain converged results. A Hedlin-Lundqvist self-energy with a constant imaginary portion was used to describe the energy dependent exchange correlation potential and the core state is treated with a Final State Rule (FSR) core hole. The Cr5O12 oxide structure used in these calculations was taken from the Materials Project (mp-13869) [33] with an orthorhombic crystal structure (-P 2n 2ab). The structure contains 3 non-equivalent chromium sites: an octahedral site (Cr0), an asymmetric tetrahedral site (Cr1) and a symmetric tetrahedral site (Cr2) appearing in a 2:1:1 relative stoichiometry, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity Propane dehydrogenation performance was evaluated for an industrial-like catalyst (Catalyst E, fresh and aged) as well as two model catalysts (Catalysts C and D) specifically prepared for this work ( Table 2). Typical Cr/Al2O3 catalysts prepared by impregnation usually contain modest levels of Cr(VI) in the fresh state, but the Cr(VI) content drastically decreases as the catalyst is aged under cyclic redox operation. The results comparing fresh and aged samples is presented in Table 2 alongside the measured Cr(VI) content. The fresh version of Catalyst E contains 1.07 wt% Cr(VI) but decreases to 0.317 wt% when aged. There is a corresponding increase of propylene selectivity from 88 to 93 wt% with the decrease in Cr(VI) concentration. A similar trend can be seen for Catalysts C and D, although the aged versions of these catalysts were not utilized for the XAS portion of this study. While the aging process may create other morphological changes in the catalyst as mentioned above, prior work has shown that these changes occur on aging times of months to years [20] whereas the aging process here was approximately one week, suggesting that the change in propylene selectivity is likely dominated by the presence, or lack thereof, of Cr(VI) species. A primary explanation for the change in propylene selectivity due to the presence of Cr(VI) species can be attributed to the acidic nature of Cr(VI) that facilitates C1-C2 byproduct formation from alkane cracking [21]. The direct influence of Cr(VI) on Cr/Al2O3 catalyst performance merits further investigation into the types of Cr(VI) present, however, the complex structural behavior of industrially relevant Cr/Al2O3 catalysts can present a challenge in studying the exact nature of Cr species, specifically those involving Cr(VI). To address this challenge, we prepared a series of carefully designed samples intended to favor the formation of Cr(VI). Mixtures A and B primarily differ by the presence or absence of Cr(VI) and catalysts C and D are poor catalysts for propane dehydrogenation but are good model catalysts for studying Cr(VI) speciation since Cr(VI) in fresh Cr/Al2O3 samples inversely tracks with total Cr content [21,22]. Although this topic has been previously considered, this work presents the first explicit effort employing XAS analysis to probe Cr(VI) speciation that forms under calcination conditions, employing near-model Cr/Al2O3 samples. 3.2 Cr(VI) formation from Al2O3 interaction Wet chemical analysis was used to determine the Cr(VI) content, and subsequent fraction for Cr(VI) compared to total Cr, in each sample highlighting how the presence of the Al2O3 and fraction of Cr interacting with the Al2O3 lead to the formation of Cr(VI) during calcination, Table 1. In the Cr2O3 standard, which was calcined from CrO3 at 600 °C, with no interaction with Al2O3, the Cr(VI) fraction is less than 2 × 10−5. The Cr(VI) fraction did not change in Mixture A (2 ×10−5), where the Cr2O3 is physically mixed with the Al2O3 but not calcined. The detection limits of the wet chemical analysis require use to consider these values to be identical, suggesting that the physical mixing is not directly responsible for Cr(VI) formation. When Mixture A is calcined, forming Mixture B, the Cr(VI) fraction increases by three orders of magnitude to 0.04 showing that the presence of Al2O3 in the sample greatly increases the extent of Cr(VI) formation during calcination. This is further exemplified in Catalysts E, C, and D where the Cr(VI) fraction increases further to 0.08, 0.71, and 0.82, respectively. Prior work has shown that X-ray diffraction peaks corresponding to the presence of Cr2O3 are not detectable at Cr loadings less than 4.6 wt% Cr but do appear and intensify with Cr loading above that [22]. The presence of defined diffraction peaks that change as a function of Cr loading show that particles form, or increase in size with Cr content. In context to the samples in this study, the amount of Cr that is interacting with the Al2O3 support is inversely proportional to Cr loading showing that increased contact with the Al2O3 is responsible for the Cr(VI) formation. 3.3 XAS analysis The Cr K-edge XANES spectra of the physically mixed Cr2O3/Al2O3 samples, Mixtures A and B, and those of the dilute CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts, Catalyst C and D, formed by different Cr precursors, are each compared to the XANES of Cr2O3 in Fig. 1. XANES spectra of Mixtures A and B, Fig. 1a, have similar edge positions and shapes matching the XANES spectra of Cr2O3. In Mixture B the XANES spectrum shows the formation of a pre-edge peak at 5993.4 eV, as well as a change in the white line shape with respect to that of bulk Cr2O3. Changes in the white line shape include a decrease in the overall intensity of the two features, as well as change in the ratio of the two peak intensities. In contrast, Fig. 1b. shows that the XANES spectra of Catalysts C and D, the incipient wetness impregnated samples, are vastly different than that of Cr2O3. Both samples have an intense pre-edge peak as well as a less pronounced white line and dampened post-edge features. The XAS spectra of the 0.6% Cr impregnated catalysts (Catalysts C and D) are helpful for identification of the structure of the species produced by re-oxidation of bulk Cr2O3 at the interface of Al2O3 given the high degree of dispersion of the Cr on the Al2O3 surface compared to the physically mixed samples. Several Cr(VI) containing compounds may be present on the surface of this catalyst including unconverted CrO3, chromium chromates, aluminum chromates, and aluminum chromium chromates (Al3+ xCr3+ 2−xCr6+ 3O12). Fig. 2 presents the XAS spectra of Catalysts C and D compared to the Cr(VI)-containing standards of Cr5O12, CrO3, and K2Cr2O7. The presence of a white line and post-edge features in the XANES spectra of Catalysts C and D make it clear that there is no unconverted, or formed, CrO3 and there is no direct match to either the chromium chromate (Cr5O12) or polychromate (K2Cr2O7) standard. The possibility of the presence of fractional components of these oxides is evaluated in the linear combination fitting section below. Unfortunately, there is no commercially obtainable standard of Al2(CrO4)3. Moreover, our many attempts to synthesize bulk Al2(CrO4)3 were also not successful suggesting that this compound can exist only on the surface or at the interface of alumina oxide. Based on the mismatch of Catalysts C and D with the bulk oxide spectra we hypothesize that XAS spectra of these catalysts is generated (in part) by the presence of aluminum chromium chromate (Al3+ xCr3+ 2−xCr6+ 3O12). The pre-edge peak observed in Mixture B and Catalysts C and D is indicative of the presence of Cr(VI) species as a prominent pre-edge peak at 5993.5 eV occurs when Cr is present as Cr(VI), caused by a bound-state ls to 3d transition. This is a forbidden transition for octahedral Cr(III)O6 which has a center of symmetry, but it is allowed for the non-centrosymmetric tetrahedral Cr(VI)O4 molecule due to mixing of Cr(3d) and O(2p) orbitals. Nevertheless, small pre-edge features are present for octahedral Cr(III) at 5990.5 and 5993.5 eV which are due to ls to 3d(t2g) and ls to 3d(eg) electronic transitions, respectively [25]. The presence of the pre-edge peak demonstrates the formation of Cr(VI) species as a result of the calcination of the CrOx/Al2O3 samples. While not giving insight into the speciation of the Cr(VI) species formed, the pre-edge peak intensity has been shown to increase linearly with Cr(VI) content in a sample [25]. A linear calibration of Cr(VI) content as a function of pre-edge peak height intensity, using bulk Cr2O3 and CrO3 to represent 100% Cr(III) and 100% Cr(VI), respectively, allowed the amount of Cr(VI) formed in each calcined sample to be determined, Fig. S2, in the SI. This value was compared to that determined by wet chemical analysis, above. Both the wet chemical analysis and the pre-edge peak intensity show an increase in Cr(VI) content after calcination and show a much larger Cr(VI) fraction in the dilute, 0.6 wt% Cr, CrOx/Al2O3 samples, Catalysts C and D, compared to the physically mixed calcined sample, Mixture B. Interestingly, calcination of Catalyst D, synthesized from a Cr(III) precursor resulted in a near identical (71 vs. 82%, Table 3) Cr(VI) fraction compared to Catalyst C, synthesized from a Cr(VI) precursor. The Cr(NO3)3 precursor in Catalyst D is expected to decompose to Cr2O3 in air. From the observations of the pre-edge peak in the Cr K-edge XANES it can be concluded that: (i) Cr(VI) existed in all calcined samples, and not bulk Cr2O3, which shows that the presence of Al2O3 is required to form Cr(VI) species, be it from a physical mixing or from wet impregnation, (ii) XAS quantification of the Cr(VI) fraction in all calcined samples overestimated the fraction compared to the wet chemical analysis, and (iii) speciation of the Cr(VI) fraction is not possible given only a small energy range. The EXAFS spectra and the magnitude of the Fourier-transform of the EXAFS spectra characterizing Mixtures A and B, Catalysts C and D, and Cr2O3 are presented in Fig. S3 in the SI. The EXAFS of Mixtures A and B are similar to that of Cr2O3 with Mixture B, the calcined physically mixed Cr2O3/Al2O3 sample, showing slight dampening of the EXAFS in the k-range of 2–7 Å−1 compared to Mixture A and bulk Cr2O3, Fig. S3a. This dampening is mimicked in the Fourier-transform with a diminished peak intensity at approximately 1.5 Å, Fig. S3b. EXAFS spectra of Catalysts C and D are vastly different than Mixtures A and B or Cr2O3. Catalysts C and D do not have any long-range order observed by lack of higher frequency components in the EXAFS, Fig. S3a, and lack of longer-range (R > 2.5 Å) scattering components in the Fourier-transform space, Fig. S3b. Catalysts C and D also have neighboring backscatterers at a shorter distance, at approximately 1.3 vs 1.5 Å, non-phase corrected, than that of Mixtures A and B or Cr2O3. Modeling of CrOx species in Cr(III) and Cr(VI) oxides is challenging due to the non-symmetric crystal structure resulting in a large number of scattering paths beyond the neighboring Cr-O paths, Fig. S4. Both Cr2O3 and CrO3 have two Cr-O scattering paths at bonding distances ranging from 1.67 to 2.0 Å. The ability to model the scattering path at 1.67 Å is used to show the presence of Cr(VI) species, and the coordination number, C.N., can be used to extract the fraction of Cr(VI) in the sample. Best-fit EXAFS models of the physically mixed samples, Mixtures A and B, only required the first two Cr-O scattering paths found in the Cr2O3 structure, Table S2 and Figs. S5-S6. It was not possible to additionally fit the Cr(VI)-O scattering path at 1.67 Å. Mixture A, the uncalcined sample, yielded a total CN of 5.2 ± 0.2 whereas Mixture B, the calcined sample, has a total coordination of 4.8 ± 0.2 for the Cr-O scattering paths at a set of distances between 1.96 and 2.01 Å. This is compared to a C.N. of 5.4 ± 0.2 at a set of similar scattering path distances for the bulk Cr2O3 standard (Fig. S7 and Table S2). Thus, we conclude that due to similarity of both the XANES and the results of the EXAFS modeling, the Cr in the as-prepared sample is consistent with a Cr2O3-like structure and the physical mixing process during synthesis did not significantly modify the Cr structure. EXAFS models (Table S3 in the SI) that included a short Cr-O path found in Cr(VI) oxides (at 1.65 Å) with the intent to identify the transition of the 6-coordinate to 4-coordinate Cr was also tested. However, while the inclusion of the path improved the R-factor, the reduced-χ2 term increased, indicating that use of additional parameters did not statistically improve the fit. Despite the inability to fit a short Cr(VI)-O scattering path the observed decrease in the overall Cr-O coordination from 5.4 to 4.8 in Mixture A and B, respectively, is consistent with the conversion of some of the 6-coordinate Cr(III) to 4-coordinate Cr(VI). This further supports the XANES observation that upon calcination some of the Cr in the physically mixed sample is converted to Cr(VI). EXAFS models characterizing the dilute CrOx/Al2O3, Catalysts C and D, were best-fit with models that contained a short scattering path at 1.67 Å, characteristic of a Cr(VI)-O interaction, and a path at 2.01 Å, characteristic of a Cr(III)-O interaction, Table S2 and Figs. S8-S9, in the SI. The presence of the scattering path at 1.67 Å clearly identified the presence of Cr(VI) in the two samples. Quantification of the Cr(VI) fraction from the best-fit EXAFS models, Table 3, showed that the Cr(VI) fraction was underestimated compared to the wet chemical analysis and pre-edge peak fitting. Additionally, the EXAFS modeling does not give any structural insight into the Cr(VI) formed as only the neighboring atoms were able to be modeled. Thus, LCF was used in attempt to better quantify both the extent of Cr(VI) formation and the bonding environment, in addition to speciation of the Cr(VI) species. 3.4 XANES linear combination fitting LCF was used to help identify (i) the speciation of the Cr(VI) fraction in Mixture B, and Catalysts C and D based upon the electronic structure of the XANES spectra and (ii) the fraction of Cr(VI) species present in the calcined samples based upon the best-fit LCF results. Table S4 shows the fit results of the 3 calcined samples. The basis spectra for each of the fits consisted of Cr2O3 and a Cr(VI) containing oxide, either Cr5O12, CrO3, or K2Cr2O7. Inspection of the fits (Figs. S10-S12 in the SI) shows a good physical match for all pairs tested for Mixture B making LCF challenging to uniquely identify the type of Cr(VI) species formed during the calcination. However, the LCF using the Cr5O12 standard gave the lowest error in the fit when comparing Reduced-χ2 (Table S4), suggesting that the Cr(VI) species formed had a structure similar to chromium chromate. Linear combination fits of Catalysts C and D were not as good, Figs. S11-S12, with notable misfits in either the approximation of the pre-edge peak intensity or the structures of the white line and XANES region. The best fits for Catalysts C and D consisted of a combination Cr2O3 and K2Cr2O7 XANES structures. This result is consistent with previous literature [23,24] showing that polychromate species form when depositing Cr on Al2O3. Cr(VI) fractional components of the best-fit LCF models were used to calculate the Cr(VI) fraction in the calcined samples, Table 3. It was determined that there was approximately 7% Cr(VI) in Mixture B, and 65% and 78% Cr(VI) in Catalysts C and D, respectively. While these results are still not completely in agreement with those in the wet chemical analysis, they show that a better Cr(VI) quantification can be obtained when using the entire XANES spectrum rather than just the pre-edge peak or through EXAFS fitting. This is likely due to the high signal-to-noise ratio in the XANES region being able to resolve subtle changes in the spectral shape [38]. Linear combination fitting was able to better resolve the quantification of Cr(VI) that formed in the calcined samples (Mixture B, and Catalysts C and D). However, the misfits in the LCF do not allow for definitive Cr(VI) speciation. Best-fit results suggest that the Cr(VI) species formed is likely chromium-chromate-like (Cr5O12) or polychromate-like (K2Cr2O7) in nature consisting of either small Cr(VI) chains or isolated Cr(VI) tetrahedra interacting with either Cr(III) octahedra, or possibly Al(III) octahedra from the support. Given the similarity in all the LCF fits for the Mixture B sample, difference spectral analysis was performed to better understand the subtle difference in the uncalcined (Mixture A) and calcined (Mixture B) sample set. 3.5 XAS difference spectra analysis Difference spectral analysis is commonly used in the excited-state materials characterization field [36,37] to extract a spectrum of a minority species that is known to be present, when a pure-component spectrum cannot be measured. This technique has been recently applied to electrocatalysts[35] in order to extract the spectrum of an unknown surface phase that formed during repeated electrochemical cycling. The same methodology has been applied here to extract out the species that is formed during the calcination of the physically mixed Cr2O3/Al2O3. A set of “unknown” Cr(VI)-containing spectra were calculated using the spectra of the calcined (Mixture B) and uncalcined (Mixture A) physically mixed Cr2O3/Al2O3 samples. Since the LCF results suggested a Cr5O12- or K2Cr2O7-like structure is formed during the calcination process the initial species fraction, x, was set based upon Mixture B’s corresponding Cr2O3 fraction, 0.88 and 0.95 for the Cr5O12 and K2Cr2O7 fits, respectively. The calculated spectra for each sample using the different component fractions are presented in Fig. 3. The two calculated spectra capture the pre-edge peak associated with the 4-coordinate Cr(VI), Fig. 3 inset, independent of the initial fraction component used. Interestingly, the calculated pre-edge peaks are shifted approximately 0.2–0.4 eV lower in energy than the pre-edge peaks in the bulk Cr5O12 or K2Cr2O7 spectra. Comparison of the entire calculated difference XANES spectra to that of the bulk standards shows that there is a greater mismatch between the x = 0.95 and the K2Cr2O12 spectra compared the x = 0.88 and Cr5O12 spectra. This further justifies that the LCF fit using Cr5O12 as one of the standards was likely the best fit. However, the difference spectra analysis shows that there are three key differences between the calculated spectra, x = 0.88, and the most similar bulk structure, Cr5O12. First, there is the abovementioned shift in the pre-edge peak position to lower energy. Second, there appears to be an additional rising edge shoulder at approximately 6000 eV. Finally, there is a sharpness in the white line and more intense features in the post-edge region of the XANES. Given the similarity of the calculated difference spectrum with lower initial species fraction (x = 0.88) to that of the Cr5O12 standard and not K2Cr2O7, we propose that the 4-coordinate Cr(VI) species formed as a result of the calcination are oriented in a corner-sharing orientation ( Scheme 1) as the other Cr(VI) oxides contain additional edge or face-sharing Cr(VI) interactions. Dissimilarities in the unknown spectra compared to that of Cr5O12 poses the question if the Cr(VI) that is formed is solely in a Cr5O12 phase, or if a Al3+ xCr3+ 2−xCr6+ 3O12-like structure is formed. Thus, FEFF XANES simulations were used to explore how the interaction of Cr(VI) tetrahedra with Al(III) octahedra instead of Cr(III) octahedra would affect the XANES spectra. 3.6 FEFF Cr K-edge XANES simulations FEFF was used to simulate the theoretical Cr XANES spectra of Al3+ xCr3+ 2−xCr6+ 3O12 using the crystallographic structure of Cr5O12. The Cr5O12 structure contains three unique Cr sites, two Cr(VI) tetrahedra, and one Cr(III) octahedron, Fig. S13 in the SI. For the XANES simulation, Al was substituted only into the Cr(III) octahedral sites. Component spectra for the Cr(III) and Al(III) containing simulations can be found in Fig. S14 in the SI. The two tetrahedral Cr(VI) sites in both simulations are characterized by an intense pre-edge peak and no white line. The Cr(III) site in the Cr5O12 simulation is characterized by a reduced pre-edge peak and an intense white line. There are notable changes to the FEFF simulated Cr K-edge XANES as the Al stoichiometry is increased from 0 to 2, Fig. 4, showing the sensitivity of the Cr K-edge XANES to its local environment. With increasing Al content in the Cr5O12 structure there are three distinct spectral changes. First, the pre-edge peak shifts to lower energy and increases in intensity. The increase in intensity of the pre-edge peak is attributed to the decreasing amount of Cr(III) sites contributing to the simulated average Cr K-edge spectra. The shift in peak position is attributed to the increased fraction of Cr(VI)-{O}-Al(III) interactions instead of Cr(VI)-{O}-Cr(III) interactions, Fig. S15, and the Al(III) having a different electronic interaction with the Cr(VI) compared to Cr(III). Second, there is a rising-edge shoulder that changes position and intensity with the Al(III) fraction in the simulated spectra. While there is no apparent electronic reason for this it appears to be a convolution of a shoulder on the edge of the Cr(III) spectrum, Fig. S14a, and the white line of the Cr(VI) spectra when neighboring octahedra are occupied by Al(III) centers, Fig. S14b. Finally, the simulated spectra show a varying intensity white line and post-edge region with well-defined features/oscillations. The white line intensity and presence of post-edge features is again dependent on the fraction of Cr(III) species present as the Cr(III) octahedra site is the only one with a white line structure and multiple oscillations after the edge. While there are notable changes between the simulated XANES spectra of Cr5O12 and Al2Cr3O12, a large fraction of the Cr(III) needs to be replaced with Al(III) before seeing changes in the spectra. The white line intensity starts to change after approximately 20% of the Cr(III) octahedra are replaced with Al and the pre-edge peak starts to change after 40%. Given the extent of spectral change required to observe the formation of an Al3+ xCr3+ 2−xCr6+ 3O12 species makes definitive identification in the calcined samples (Mixture B, and Catalysts C and D) difficult, however, comparisons of the measured or difference spectra can be used to identify if the same trends exist in the sample spectra, suggesting the formation of Al(III) octahedra interacting with Cr(VI) tetrahedra. Fig. 5 and S16–17 highlight the three key regions that show the spectral features associated with a Cr(VI) tetrahedron interacting with Al(III) octahedra. All three calcined samples show that (i) there is an observed shift in the pre-edge peak position from 0.05 to 0.3 eV consistent with a Cr(VI)-{O}-Al(III) interaction; (ii) the rising edge has a low energy shoulder similar to that found in the FEFF-simulated Al3+ 2Cr6+ 3O12 spectra, Fig. 4; and (iii) there are white line and additional post-edge features observed when there are Cr(VI) tetrahedra interacting with both Cr(III) and Al(III) octahedra, Fig. 4, between 6020 and 6040 eV. From this we infer that in the presence of Al2O3, oxidized chromium, be it either crystalline Cr2O3 in contact with the Al2O3 or deposited on the surface through incipient wetness using Cr(III) or Cr(VI) precursors, will react with the Al2O3 surface forming aluminum chromium chromate species (Al3+ xCr3+ 2−xCr6+ 3O12) where the Cr(VI) tetrahedra are corner sharing with both Al(III) and Cr(III) octahedra. 4 Conclusions Calcination of physically mixed Cr2O3 and Al2O3 materials as well as impregnated Cr/Al2O3 catalysts (with either Cr(III) or Cr(VI) precursors), leads to the formation of new Cr(VI) species, as clearly determined using Cr K-edge XAS. Catalytic activity measurements reveal the importance of understanding and controlling the formation of Cr(VI) species as propylene selectivity inversely tracks with Cr(VI) content under propane dehydrogenation conditions. When compared to wet chemical analysis, quantification of the fraction of Cr(VI) present in the calcined samples is over estimated when only considering the pre-edge peak in the Cr K-edge XANES spectra, and it is underestimated when determined by EXAFS analysis based upon the coordination number of short (1.67 Å) Cr(VI)-O or long (2.01 Å) Cr(III)-O scattering paths. Linear combination fitting does a better job at approximating the Cr(VI) content of a calcined sample, but misfits make it impossible to conclusively describe the chemical speciation of the Cr(VI) species. A combination of LCF and difference spectra analysis reveal that the Cr(VI) formed during calcination is likely in a Cr5O12 structure consisting of edge-sharing octahedra. Cr K-edge FEFF XANES simulations show that the chromium K-absorption edge is extremely sensitive to its local environment and could be useful for determining whether the Cr(VI) was interacting with Cr(III) or Al(III). Similarities between XAS spectra of chromium chromate, Cr catalyst containing surface aluminum chromates and Cr(VI) formed by reoxidation of Cr2O3 on the interface of Al2O3 strongly suggest that this Cr(VI)-containing compound is chromium chromate (Cr5O12) that also include aluminum in its structure similar to Al3+ xCr3+ 2−xCr6+ 3O12. coredata.dc:description: The CATOFIN© process produces propylene from propane using a CrOx /Al2O3 catalyst. Despite its use, there are still uncertainties surrounding the nature of Cr species formed during synthesis, regeneration, and aging. It has been observed that ppm levels of Cr2O3 can be oxidized to Cr(VI) in air; however, when Cr2O3 is in direct contact with Al2O3, Cr(VI) formation increased more than 100-fold. To confirm physical contact between Cr2O3 and Al2O3 results in increased Cr(VI) formation, Cr2O3 and Cr2O3/Al2O3 samples were synthesized, calcined, and characterized. Catalytic activity measurements confirm propylene selectivity inversely tracks with Cr(VI). Wet chemical titration and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) quantified and determined the structure of the Cr(VI) species. FEFF X-ray absorption near edge structure simulations determined the potential sensitivity of the XAS to the presence of Al3+/Cr3+ neighboring atoms. XAS correlated to FEFF simulations suggested that Al3+ xCr3+ 2−xCr6+ 3O12 comprises a significant fraction of the Cr(VI) species formed.
